unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Situations for a One Proportion Z Test
question_text: In which of the following situations would it be appropriate to use a one-proportion Z-test?

choices.text: Determine whether males are more likely to vote Republican than females are.
Determine if a political candidate will get at least $50\%$ of the vote in an upcoming election.
Determine if an association exists between favorite type of music and socioeconomic status.
Determine the proportion of people who prefer Coke over Pepsi in a blind taste test.
Determine if students who study on a regular basis score higher on the ACT than their peers who do not study on a regular basis.

solution:
Choice 'A' is incorrect; this situation deals with two populations (males and females), so a two-proportion Z-test would be appropriate.

Choice 'B' is correct; this situation deals with a single proportion; specifically, the proportion who would vote for the political candidate.

Choice 'C' is incorrect; this selection deals with two categorical variables, each with several proportions, so a chi-squared test for association would be appropriate.

Choice 'D' is incorrect. While this situation does deal with a single proportion, an interval, not a test would best determine the true proportion who prefer Coke over Pepsi in a blind taste test.

Choice 'E' is incorrect. This situation deals with sample means, not proportions. A one sample or possibly two sample T procedure could be used here depending on how the data was collected.
